author: vorot93
content:
Proxy-delegate does not involve modifying deployed contract.

I think the big problem in this community is ppl speaking out of their butt, without knowing how Ethereum clients are actually written.

Proliferation of such proposals in the past has led us to a situation that only a handful of people actually know how Ethereum implementations work. As a result - client maintenance crisis on our hands.

The more sources of complexity we remove, the sooner said crisis will resolve. SELFDESTRUCT is a _major_ source of complexity.

author: roshanroshan
content:
well yeah, ofc proxy-delegates don't mutate contracts, apologies if I wasn't clear there, I was talking more from the _user's_ perspective
as a user today, I can not rely on "immutable" behaviour as long as proxy-delegates are a thing
I would have to audit the contract to see how it might change in the future, at which point it doesn't really matter if the contract can mutate, I'm auditing it anyway

and I'm not arguing against removing `SELFDESTRUCT` either, literally don't care if this stays or not
in fact, me referencing the above post by Vitalik was more to understand what sort of second-order effects to _avoid_ when debating a new opcode

point well taken about client complexity though

author: roshanroshan
content:
people can do proxies, yes, (and they do it today) but the main thing I'm trying to address is the gas that's wasted in all this crap (bonus: save some witness size, albeit small)
it was completely fine when `SLOAD` costed 200, but its currently 10x that and makes reading _any_ storage an expensive proposition, especially when it lies in the hot path for _every_ transaction made to a contract
not to mention, state size is still growing (at least until we get some sort or pruning/archival to stabilize it), which potentially means costs go up _regularly_

and its not just about upgrades, another big example is governance parameters which currently reside in contract storage
each param is an extra `SLOAD` on almost _every_ call made to the contract, which is a total waste, an ideal world would have it encoded in the contract bytecode itself and mutate when it changes (paying higher upfront costs for lower ongoing costs)

I'm sure other use cases will pop up...

I'll admit that I'm kinda just handwaving a lot of things here, maybe I should try to get some numbers on how much gas is being wasted on all this BS
I think that will probably put it into context (for me, included) if its _worth_ the client complexity or not
